title: Feds reach nearly $2B legal settlement with fertilizer maker
text:
GAINESVILLE, Fla. (AP) - One of the world's largest fertilizer makers has settled a massive hazardous waste lawsuit with federal regulators for nearly $2 billion to help clean up pollution and close leaky old facilities in Florida and Louisiana.
The U.S. Department of Justice and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency were set to announce the settlement on Thursday with Minnesota-based The Mosaic Co.
The legal agreement, which still needs court approval, concerns the proper storage and disposal of more than 60 billion tons of hazardous waste.
Mosaic makes a commonly used phosphorus-based fertilizer, the production of which creates acidic hazardous waste and polluted water.
That waste is stored in 500-foot-high piles that span more than 600 acres at facilities in Florida and Louisiana.
